stream_context.summary: Kaze iterates on the desert/railroad level: re-texturing quicksand, experimenting with fog colours, adding distant cliff billboards, and testing real-hardware performance while discussing upcoming engine optimisations and a missing graphics teammate.

development_findings.summary: Decided against animated quicksand and instead blends a lighter sand texture into fixed blue fog to signal the kill-plane without costly alpha fades.
development_findings.quote: Making things fade to blue would make things look like they're disappearing, whereas the sand at the bottom would always make it feel like they're on the ground in the distance.

development_findings.summary: Introduced parallax cliff billboards on a separate draw layer; uses fog to mask edges and reduce overdraw while preserving depth.
development_findings.quote: We have a second layer, we get a little parallax effect… it's very cheap to render too.

development_findings.summary: Cannot use shade-alpha combiners across the whole level; large 64×64 sand texture cannot scroll cheaply, so static math-based skybox clouds were adopted.
development_findings.quote: Not being able to use shade alpha throughout the entire level is such a big limitation.

development_findings.summary: Performance test on real N64 shows 25-30 FPS with 10 k triangles, no culling planes, and stock F3DEX2; enabling culling and new F3DEX3 is expected to push it higher.
development_findings.quote: We’re not even culling these buildings… 30 FPS—that’s crazy.

development_findings.summary: Current build exposes an RSP bottleneck; Sauraen is preparing a variant of F3DEX3 with lighter RSP costs to regain speed.
development_findings.quote: He thinks that in Return to Yoshi's Island the memory and RDP is so optimised that with F3DEX3 the RSP becomes the bottleneck.

development_findings.summary: Fast64 keeps overwriting manual hex edits, so Kaze now stores critical combiner strings in Discord to paste back quickly.
development_findings.quote: Is there a way I can make this work next time I export so I don't have to deal with Fast64 resetting my hex edits? The only way I see is to use coloured sand from the get-go.

development_findings.summary: Blue fog palette was locked in early; changing it now would break established lighting, so all new geometry is colour-matched to that fog.
development_findings.quote: No, I want the blue colours. That's already decided… It is too late to undo that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is frustrated with YouTube’s drama-bait recommendations and values the 'power of not caring'.
context_findings.quote: Almost every video I'm recommended is some meaningless drama… Of course I don't get rage-baited; I just get annoyed that it's there.

context_findings.summary: He sees marketing value in retro hardware novelty: an N64 game with a simultaneous PC port would generate free publicity.
context_findings.quote: If you have the marketing of 'hey, this is an N64 game, but there's also a PC port', it's kind of insane. That would make the news.

biobak.summary: Has been absent for an extended period despite plans to help re-work several levels; Kaze expresses concern.
biobak.quote: Has anyone seen Biobak recently? He wanted to help me rework a bunch of levels. I hope he's not gone.

key_stories.title: Fixing the fog-cliff mismatch
key_stories.summary: When distant cliffs adopted the same RGB as scene fog, Fast64’s additional level fog layer shifted hues, causing an obvious seam. Kaze traced the issue to level-specific fog saturation and re-balanced both colours.
key_stories.challenge: Cliff billboards looked disconnected from the skybox because their colour didn’t match the distance fog.
key_stories.process: Tested combiner math, examined hex, realised level fog overrides, adjusted fog saturation and prim colour.
key_stories.outcome: Seamless blend and clear visual boundary without re-texturing everything.
key_stories.key_quote: I know what the issue is—the actual level fog is applying to this and ruining the colour.

key_stories.title: Discovering an RSP bottleneck
key_stories.summary: A hardware test showed F3DEX3 ran slower only on Kaze’s build. Sauraen deduced Return to Yoshi's Island is so RDP-efficient that the RSP now limits speed.
key_stories.challenge: Why does F3DEX3 lag only on Kaze’s ROM while others are fine?
key_stories.process: Discussed with Sauraen; compared performance; isolated RSP workload as culprit.
key_stories.outcome: Sauraen is coding an RSP-lighter F3DEX3; Kaze expects an 'instant huge performance boost'.
key_stories.key_quote: He said he thinks that in Return to Yoshi's Island the memory and RDP is so optimised that the RSP becomes the bottleneck.

key_stories.title: External studio pitches new N64 title
key_stories.summary: A company approached Kaze about producing a new commercial N64 game for release in 2024; decision expected in June.
key_stories.challenge: Assess feasibility and marketability of shipping a brand-new cartridge in 2024.
key_stories.process: Initial conversation; Kaze analyses built-in marketing appeal of retro hardware.
key_stories.outcome: Project undecided but regarded as 'pretty hype' if green-lit.
key_stories.key_quote: There was a company that approached me recently and they said they want to make an N64 game in 2024… If they do make one, that would be pretty hype.

open_questions.context: Kaze hasn’t heard from the lead graphics artist who was slated to help re-work several levels.
questions: Have you re-established contact with Biobak?
Which specific levels was he set to overhaul?
Do you have contingency plans if he remains unavailable?

open_questions.context: Sauraen is preparing a variant but no timeline was given.
questions: What specific RSP functions are being rewritten?
Will this fork require level-side changes?

open_questions.context: Multiple visual ideas (additional cliffs, dynamic clouds, dynamic lighting) were floated but not finalised.
questions: Which elements are locked in for the shipping build?
Will dynamic lighting make the cut on real hardware?
How will the second area’s skybox differ?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned hopes of releasing RTYI alongside an OST cartridge.
questions: What hardware/mapper will the cartridge use?
How will copyright be handled for any Nintendo-derived melodies?
Can you share the studio’s name?
What genre or concept is proposed?
